title: Nigeria: At least 18 people killed, 48 others injured in bomb blasts in Borno
content: At least 18 people were killed and 48 injured in bomb blasts in Nigeria's Borno state, CNN reported. The first explosion hit a wedding, followed by blasts at General Hospital Gwoza and a funeral. Borno State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA) confirmed men, women, and children among the deceased. SEMA Director General Barkindo Muhammad Saidu visited the site.
summary: At least 18 people were killed and 48 injured in bomb blasts in Nigeria's Borno state, CNN reported. The first explosion hit a wedding, followed by blasts at General Hospital Gwoza and a funeral. Borno State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA) confirmed men, women, and children among the deceased. SEMA Director General Barkindo Muhammad Saidu visited the site.

title: Suspected suicide bombers kill at least 18 in Nigeria, authorities say
content: Barkindo Saidu, director general of the Borno State Emergency Management Agency, said suspected suicide bombers separately attacked a wedding, funeral and hospital, killing and injuring several people in the town of Gwoza. Saidu said 18 deaths had been confirmed, a toll that included children, adults and pregnant women. "The degree of injuries ranges from abdominal ruptures, scull fractures, and limb fractures," he said. Borno is at the centre of a 15-year Islamist insurgency that has killed thousands of people and displaced millions more.
summary: Barkindo Saidu, director general of the Borno State Emergency Management Agency, said suspected suicide bombers separately attacked a wedding, funeral and hospital, killing and injuring several people in the town of Gwoza. Saidu said 18 deaths had been confirmed, a toll that included children, adults and pregnant women. "The degree of injuries ranges from abdominal ruptures, scull fractures, and limb fractures," he said. Borno is at the centre of a 15-year Islamist insurgency that has killed thousands of people and displaced millions more.

title: China's June factory activity contracts for second month
content: In the face of economic challenges, China's manufacturing sector struggles, prompting the need for stimulus measures. Disappointing output numbers, uncertain export sales sustainability, and a persistent property crisis add to the complexity, requiring interventions to boost investment and counter the sluggish growth.
summary: In the face of economic challenges, China's manufacturing sector struggles, prompting the need for stimulus measures. Disappointing output numbers, uncertain export sales sustainability, and a persistent property crisis add to the complexity, requiring interventions to boost investment and counter the sluggish growth.

title: A private call of top Democrats fuels more insider anger about Biden's debate performance
content: Democratic leaders are concerned about Biden's debate performance impact, prompting calls for him to step aside. Despite this, Biden and his allies remain confident in his ability to compete against Trump. Post-debate polling results are eagerly awaited to gauge the situation.
summary: Democratic leaders are concerned about Biden's debate performance impact, prompting calls for him to step aside. Despite this, Biden and his allies remain confident in his ability to compete against Trump. Post-debate polling results are eagerly awaited to gauge the situation.

Afghan women's rights an internal issue, says Taliban ahead of UN talks
content: Taliban authorities in a press briefing stated that demands over women's rights were "Afghanistan's issues" to solve, ahead of United Nations-led engagement talks where the exclusion of Afghan women has sparked outcry. Rights groups have condemned the exclusion of Afghan women from the main meetings and the lack of human rights issues on the agenda.
summary: Taliban authorities in a press briefing stated that demands over women's rights were "Afghanistan's issues" to solve, ahead of United Nations-led engagement talks where the exclusion of Afghan women has sparked outcry. Rights groups have condemned the exclusion of Afghan women from the main meetings and the lack of human rights issues on the agenda.

title: 5 bombs found in iconic Iraq mosque, planted years ago by IS: UN agency
content: A United Nations agency said it has discovered five bombs in a wall of Mosul's iconic Al-Nuri mosque, planted years ago by Islamic State group jihadists, during restoration work in the northern Iraqi city. Five "large-scale explosive devices, designed to trigger a massive destruction of the site," were found in the southern wall of the prayer hall on Tuesday by the UNESCO team working at the site, a representative for the agency told AFP late Friday.
summary: A United Nations agency said it has discovered five bombs in a wall of Mosul's iconic Al-Nuri mosque, planted years ago by Islamic State group jihadists, during restoration work in the northern Iraqi city. Five "large-scale explosive devices, designed to trigger a massive destruction of the site," were found in the southern wall of the prayer hall on Tuesday by the UNESCO team working at the site, a representative for the agency told AFP late Friday.

title: Iran presidential elections: Runoff between reformist Pezeshkian and hard-liner Jalili; what are the rules
Iran seesawing vote results put race between reformist Masoud Pezeshkian and hard-liner Saeed Jalili
A pink blob with beady eyes: Robot with 'living skin' and a pretty smile
content: University of Tokyo professor Shoji Takeuchi has developed a robot with "living skin," gaining attention for its human-like features. Engineered with 3D-printed lab-grown meat, biological muscle tissue, and advanced adhesion technology, the robot mimics human skin-ligament structures. Future goals include adding features like sweat glands and achieving more lifelike movement, promising applications in medicine and robotics.
summary: University of Tokyo professor Shoji Takeuchi has developed a robot with "living skin," gaining attention for its human-like features. Engineered with 3D-printed lab-grown meat, biological muscle tissue, and advanced adhesion technology, the robot mimics human skin-ligament structures. Future goals include adding features like sweat glands and achieving more lifelike movement, promising applications in medicine and robotics.

title: US military destroys seven drones, vehicle in Yemen's Houthi-control region
content: Over the past 24 hours, US forces have destroyed seven drones and a control station vehicle in areas of Yemen controlled by the Huthis. The US Central Command stated that the strikes were carried out in response to an imminent threat to US coalition forces and merchant vessels in the region. The Huthis are an Iran-backed group that has been targeting vessels in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden since November 2023. They claim their attacks are in solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.
summary: Over the past 24 hours, US forces have destroyed seven drones and a control station vehicle in areas of Yemen controlled by the Huthis. The US Central Command stated that the strikes were carried out in response to an imminent threat to US coalition forces and merchant vessels in the region. The Huthis are an Iran-backed group that has been targeting vessels in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden since November 2023. They claim their attacks are in solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in the Gaza Strip.

title: Arizona wildfire: Firefighters battle to control blaze; tankers, helicopters come to aid
'Not stranded': Nasa insists Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams 'enjoying their time' at space station
content: Nasa astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams, aboard Boeing's Starliner, remain at the ISS as engineers address thruster and helium leak issues. Nasa's Steve Stich assures their safety and no rush to return. Ground tests are planned. Despite challenges, the astronauts are assisting ISS operations, and provisions are sufficient for an extended stay.
summary: Nasa astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams, aboard Boeing's Starliner, remain at the ISS as engineers address thruster and helium leak issues. Nasa's Steve Stich assures their safety and no rush to return. Ground tests are planned. Despite challenges, the astronauts are assisting ISS operations, and provisions are sufficient for an extended stay.
